reviewText:
SHORT VERSION
Do you like great fighting games? If you answered yes, then go get it. It's a good buy.

LONG VERSION
BlazBlue: Calamity Trigger is a 2D fighting game, and the first entry of the BlazBlue franchise followed by Continuum Shift and Chrono Phantasma.

Calamity Trigger features 12 fighters, each with their unique gameplay, strengths and weaknesses.
As a fighting game it's important to mention that the game can be played excellent on keyboard without any trouble. The combos are fairly easy, and you will always find new ways to chain them into better ones.
The controls are responsive and there's no delay at all. Graphics wise the game looks gorgeous: the 2D sprite models are looking good, and blend well into the 3D background, while animations are smooth and beautiful as well.
Aside from the usual story mode, there is an Arcade mode for every character, mini-games and tons of unlockable artworks to keep you busy for a long time!

However like most games, Calamity Trigger has its' flaws too: first off the Developers removed the multiplayer, though it was part of the game for the Games For Windows Live release, and second the game tends to have 30 FPS limit sometimes due to a bug. To fix the 30FPS limit you have to restart your PC, aside from this issue, the game runs smooth with 60FPS cap.

Overall Blazblue: Calamity Trigger is an amazing fighting game. I can highly recommend this to anyone, whether you're new to fighting games or a veteran in the genre.
And as a Guilty Gear/Blazblue fan is a no-brainer to buy, since it increases the chance of seeing more recent games from the developers on Steam!


PRO
- Graphics are beautiful. The 2D sprite models seemlessly blends into the 3D background.
- Animations looking smooth and nice.
- Soundtrack is amazing.
- The game features 2 different language voice acting: Japanese and English. Both are solid.
- Controls are responsive. The game plays smooth. Combos are easy to pull off. Can be played with keyboard without any difficulties.

CONS
- Lack of multiplayer.
- Occational 30 FPS cap bug. To fix the FPS limit you have to restart your PC.
- Steam cloud doesn't work, though it's shown on store page.

I'm not a big fan of anime or 2D Street-Fighter type fighting games in general. That being said, BlazBlue: Calamity Trigger is a huge exception and although I have only really scraped the surface of the game so far, I enjoyed every minute of it! Here are some of my observations:

-The number of characters to select from is relatively small but this is no doubt made up for with the fact that they are all so unique in playstyle and personality. Some of them even use their own energy systems to pull off combos, which really adds depth to the learning curve.

-While learning every characters unique play-style is difficult and time consuming, the basic controls are pretty easy to grasp. The combat seems to be mostly based on momentum and pulling off sick combos that hardly let your opponent hit the floor, but that is not to say that it's impossible to come back from a beating. I wouldn't recommend using a keyboard to play this game. It is much smoother and enjoyable with a gamepad or preferably a joystick setup. I got by just fine using a gamepad.

-There is an overwhelming amount of content as far as the story goes. Every one of the characters has an interesting, somewhat silly, story line with many twists and turns depending on how you play.

-10/10 on the soundtrack, it's pure gold. It compliments the games style perfectly and is one of the best things about this game in my opinion.

-Currently, online multiplayer is non-existent and this definitely hurts the games replayability quite a bit. Thankfully there is a lot to do with the story and offline vs. bots, but I can't help but feel that the game is incomplete without online capabilities.

All in all, BlazBlue: Calamity Trigger is a great game despite it's lacking of multiplayer. If you are a fan of anime, you're sure to fall in love with it right away!

One of the best fighting games out there, as can be expected from Arc System Works. This may be an outdated game, gameplay-wise (multiple new editions have come out since this one, with new characters, balance changes and continued story and such), but I think it's still worth getting the first game for the sake of the story mode. The story mode of this series is actually quite rich and detailed with a very thought out lore and world (rare for this genre) with very lovable and charming characters and funny situations, and in a gorgeous visual novel style. Other than that, there is arcade mode and versus with a very expansive gallery mode to collect for.

My favorite thing about BlazBlue other than the story mode is how unique each fighter plays. They are totally distinct from each other, and in more ways than your usual fighting game because of their Drives. Drives are a special ability each character has unique to them. For instance, one character's drive attacks steal a little bit of HP with each hit, and another's freezes them, and another controls a puppet, or pulls you in with magnetism, or summons flying swords out of thin air. Just awesome stuff, and it makes the characters so much fun to play as. This is a 4-button fighting game, with weak (A), medium (B), heavy (C) and drive (D) attacks. And last but not least, the taunt button! It's a really sophisticated combat system, and it's just outstanding. Also, the graphics and music and overall presentation of the game are just absolutely beautiful.

For $10, this is certainly worth the price, especially when that includes the amazing soundtrack. Hopefully this means the sequels get on Steam eventually too, as well as more from Arc System Works in general.

Unofortunately, this version of the game doesn't include online multiplayer, since it was sacrificed in order to get it here without Games for Windows Live. For me, that's a worthy trade-off, but for others it might not be. This is a fantastic game and I am so glad it has finally made it to Steam, but buyer beware.

Also, it is blue.

Ragna feels like a pretty standard melee character and is a good way to get used to how to the game works, but then you also get characters like Nu, who doesn't play like anything I've ever seen before, with a focus on ranged attacks without the use of complex inputs. The cast is a little smaller than I'd like, but this is unavoidable due to the age of the game; unfortunately we have yet to see any PC ports past the first game.

The art and sound design are also top-notch, just as they were in Guilty Gear, though this game is considerably more modern and much prettier graphically than the even more aged Guilty Gear titles available on PC. Game runs well too, with a pretty steady 60 FPS even on my fairly weak machine. There's no online multiplayer, but for someone like me who tends to get walked all over online in fighting games by the people who play the game more seriously, that's fine by me. In addition to the arcade mode, which does have little clips of story here and there, there's also a full-fledged story mode that plays out like a visual novel and adds some content to help keep things from getting stale.

Overall BlazBlue is probably going to be my go-to fighting game going forward. It's not perfect, but I've been enjoying my time with it immensely (especially Noel's combos, my God). The only thing this game is missing as far as I'm concerned is BANG BANG BANG BANG BA-BANG! If that song played every Bang fight, no, every fight, no, at all times, I would be a happy man.

reviewText:
A little late to be writing about this, but still wanted to as I really enjoyed this game. Surprise as this is coming from someone who didn't really enjoy or have any interest in the genre outside of Super Smash Brothers (if you even want to count that, I consider it more of a beat-em-up) and a couple oddball games like Soul Caliber and Virtua Fighter 5 as well as even a Street Fighter game, none really caught my attention until I bought this on a whim. Just like with Skyrim, I wanted to give it another chance, maybe I'd find something enjoyable here that I didn't with the other games and did I ever.

The first thing that I loved most about this game was the art style, the main reason why it was high on my list. That annnd it was on sale...heh. After playing a bit of the Arcade and Story, I immediately fell in love with the game and all it's characters who really shine in their own unique way. Each one plays vastly different from the other, though there are a couple who play kind of similarly. BlazBlue is a game worth picking up if you're are wanting some gameplay with some excitement, a low-ish skill floor but a very, very high skill ceiling compared to some other titles.

While playing through, you notice you have all your attacks plus a special? Yes, this ability, called the Drive, allows your character to do neat attacks such as regain health, control a puppet or chain some gunplay. Along with the amazing roster of characters you can play, there's also a mode to go through each of their tales to figure out the overaching story (as of me writing this, I have not finished it, but am about ~70% the way through).  I believe that this is where the game shines brightest alongside the amazing characters. As you go through, they become memorable because of their personality as well as movesets. I'm really loving the story, though it might not be for everyone as it makes you try to put together all the pieces which may seem more of a chore than fun.

There's also a vast gallery where you can unlock art and movies, all of which are really well-designed. Again, I really love the art and aesthetics of this game, the music is alright, nothing too special although some are relaxing yet give a nice tone when you do listen. Surely there's nothing wrong with such an amazing title. Well, there is and probably the greatest downfall, a lack of an online multiplayer and a tutorial. You're pretty much left to either play single player or get a friend with another controller/keyboard. From what I've read around, it's because it is a port from the original XBox launch. Still, it's a nice game worth the time I've put into it. I highly recommend using an Xbox controller or an arcade stick if you want to play.

You probably noticed I said high skill ceiling. That's the greatest thing I've found out about this game, a lot of the characters you can pretty much mash buttons and still do damage. However, with practice you can do some pretty amazing things. I'm pretty sure that this goes for a lot of fighters, though I think it's a lot more noticeable in here. If you're looking for a nice entry into fighting games, I highly suggest giving this a try, the replayability, while little, is really worth it for those who are looking for something nicely competitve.

reviewText:
I was never much into fighting games...
Until I played this one.
Blazblue: Calamity Trigger is one of the best fighting games I've ever played (and I've played some in all my gaming years). Most games in this style just demand that the player keep pressing buttons to win, or keep spaming the same movements over and over again. This is not the case here. The learning curve of Calamity Trigger is not easy, but it's certainly rewarding.
You have 12 characters to play from, and to some, this may be a small amount to play with. But the thing here is that you don't have two characters who have a similar style. Everyone has different fighting mechanics, and certainly, one of them will become your favorite:
You have Ragna the Bloodedge, who fights with both his giant sword, and using his fists and kicks, and is able to drain life from his opponent when he uses his Azure Grimmoire. There is Jin Kisaragi, who have a sword similar to a katana, and has ice powers. There is Noel Vermillion, who uses two giant pistols. There is Rachel Alucard, who is similar to a lady doll from the noble parts of society, who uses his shapeshifting cat and his sidekick to move graceously in the battlefield. Use her special movement (Those are called Distortion Drive in this game) early in the battle, and you will probably miss, but try to spread Lighting Rods and then using the Distortion, and all of them will get energized by the movement. Some of the characters even use their Heat Gauge (Used to make Distortion Drives) differently from other characters, and this variety of gameplay is one of the things that makes this franchise killer, not mentioning all the counter movements, throws, defensive maneuvers and ways to even use your Heat Gauge to extend combos.
The story is another major point of this game. You have 10 character's story mode to complete. Two of them are not included. In each campaign, you have different routes in the story based on some dialog choices, and even losing specific battles will not result in Game Over, rather opening another path to go on. Even the way you finish your battles may alter the route. Every character's story mode has a percentage of completion, and to get 100%, you will need to see every possible outcome. This way, you will be able to reach the true ending of that character's campaign...but does that mean the other ones are alternative endings? Check to story and draw your own conclusions.
In Calamity Trigger, you basically have the Story, Versus, Score Attack and Arcade modes. In the Arcade, you will choose one character to defeat 10 others, and in specific encounters, you will even have a dialog. It's a simple game mode, but not short of surprises. Some interesting rewards await those who complete it.
The game is completely dubbed, both in japanese and english, and has subtitles as well. I didn't play in English, but the Japanese one is awesome, as expected.
The only let-down is that it has no online mode, but trust me, you will spend dozens of hours in this game if you want to take the most of it.
Finally, it has one of the most amazing soundtracks I've ever heard. It's a mix of classical music and heavy metal, and if you're into that style of music, you will be delighted. Best of all, you will get the full digital OST in MP3 buying this.
That said, Blazblue: Calamity Trigger is recommended both to the ones who enjoy an awesome fighting game, and to those you're just getting started in that genre. Trust me, you will not be disappointed.

reviewText: So, BlazBlue. Never played the actual game until now, but I had Bang, Tager, Rachel, Noel, and Ragna for MUGEN, so I was curious to see where they were from. How is the game? Surprisingly good for a 2D 1v1 fighter. I never got into games like Mortal Combat and Street Fighter because they didn't seem very interesting. You didn't know much about the characters, they all looked the same, and they just seemed like something you would just play at a friends house.(note that not all of these statements are neccessarily true, because I never did play them) BlazBlue, however, focuses on only twelve characters, which is small for a fighting game roster in this day and age. Because of this, they all look different, all use different tactics, and all play differently, with a few extreme examples. You've got Ragna, the all-rounder and face of the game, a man who wears a trenchcoat-shaped cliche and wields a big sword, Noel, who uses dual pistols which behave unlike most pistols I've seen, V-13, which is somehow pronounced 'Nu', who animates eight floating blades for attack and defense, and Taokaka, a cat-person with massive claws and some truly impressive speed. These all use the same controls and are usable by pretty much everyone to good effect. But then you've got Akumen and Rachel, who play completely differently. Add to this variety a story mode for each character, and you've got something I didn't expect from this genre. Other than the story mode, there's a versus mode, training mode, Arcade mode, Score attack, and that's it.\nThe art design is consistently interesting, and all the stages are distinct from each other. Music is pretty good, but nothing standout. Gameplay wise, it's pretty balanced. A few characters have really powerful attacks that are balanced by their completely different playstyles, which lends the characters variety without making some of them overpowered.\nOverall, it's a fun game, and it's only ten bucks. I recommend it.

reviewText:
While I've been a fan of this series ever since my friend told me about it a couple years ago, I never actually played any of the games due to not having a PS3 or an Xbox 360. I know that this game was on PC over in the UK and on GFWL and such, but I never bothered to get that since I didn't feel like it was worth it, not to mention the price. So when I saw this on steam, I jumped at the chance. I DID take a look at the steam information on this game and I still bought it. So let's get on with the good and the bad.

Pros:
- Graphics. I really like the sprites and detailed backgrounds in the stages. I'm not the sort of guy who thinks games are only as good as their graphics. Not at all. But the game's graphics is a plus for me.
- Awesome music. I think everyone already knows that pretty much every game has at least some good music. Fighting games generally have awesome music. You get the OST when you buy this game and it's so worth it.
- Length. I've played 9.6 hours as of this review, and I'm not even halfway done with the story. The story has branching paths depending on whether you win, lose, win with a distortion/astral heat, or choose different options in the story when the choice arises (There's a guide in the community hub to help you get 100% on all character's stories). There's only three characters that have an astral heat when you first start the game. To get the others, you have to beat arcade mode with the character you want the astral heat for. You can also unlock Unlimited mode for characters, which just makes them more powerful, by having more speed, power, modified distortions, etc. That also adds a bit more to the length. Beside that, there's also score attack to do and the gallery to complete if you wanted to do those things.
- Price. You get all of this for $10. I think I got like at least $20 worth from playing some of the character's stories and listening to the OST alone.

Cons:
-No online play. For me, I don't really care too much that this game doesn't have online versus. I know that fighting games are really all about playing against someone else and most places don't have a local fighting scene. However I will say that online play is never recommended for top play. It's fine for beginner-intermediate play, but there's always some sort of latency that to play extremely competitively online in a fighting game is sort of absurd. But while I don't care too much that it's offline only, I still would've liked to see it have online. H2 Interactive might be able to implement it in the future.
- Bugs. This is a straight port of the GFWL version, so all the bugs on there are also on here. Sometimes your game will be locked at 30 FPS if your computer's been on for a while. This can easily be fixed with a restart. When I first started the game, the FPS was actually locked at around 17 FPS, but again restarting my computer fixed that. There's also a bug for some people where story mode does not have music at all. If you alt+tab out of the window and come back in, sometimes the characters' sprites will be invisible or have weird hitbox colors. These can usually be fixed if you alt+tab again or have the sprites change (either by hitting, getting hit, or anything else that changes the sprites). Same thing happens in story mode's cutscenes. Alt+tabbing will usually make the character completely invisible, or partly invisible, and the only way for that to be fixed is if the character moves somehow due to an event in the story. But it'll only happen for that one scene you alt+tabbed out of. It may also crash on certain parts, I've read about how some people are crashing after clearing score attack but I haven't played that mode yet.
- Controller support. Despite it saying Full controller support, it only fully supports Xbox controllers and anything using Xbox. My PS2 controller doesn't work, but my Madcatz TE Xbox 360 stick does work. For any other controllers, you'll have to find a way to emulate the Xbox 360 controller or maybe use one of those controller mapping programs. I have no experience with those so I'm just glad I got an Xbox 360 stick instead of a PS3 one (Though I would very much like to have one still).
-Not entirely beginner-friendly. There's absolutely no tutorial on what you can do. There is a manual if you right click the game and read it (but who really does that? I didn't even know about it until I right clicked it once). So you'll have to either go into training mode and test out your things or read a guide or something. Basically each character has a light attack, medium attack, and heavy attack, recognized as A, B, and C respectively. Each character also has a Drive attack, recognized as D. Every single attack also has a forward+ action, so if you hold forward and press A, B, C, or D, you'll do a different attack than just pressing A, B, C, or D by itself. Same thing for in the air, though I believe it depends on certain characters. Arakune, for example, has a down+A/B/C attack in the air. Pressing A+B at the same time gives you a barrier block, which is different from a normal block, obviously. There's also an instant block and instant barrier block, if you block about 8 frames before an attack connects. B+C is your grab attack. A+B+C consumes 50 heat, and allows you to cancel a move. A+B+C+D is your burst, which lets you get out of a combo. Not recommended to use early in the round, since you won't have a barrier gauge and will be in Danger status until the round ends. However, definitely recommended if you're supposed to lose in story mode to get a certain scene or path.

Overall, I would still recommend this game. If you have never played a BlazBlue game but wanted to, I'd say go for it. If you want to experience the story, go for it. If you want to get familiar with BlazBlue games, go for it (Although each new game changes something). Despite the cons, I still really enjoyed the game and will enjoy it for many more hours to come. The story and OST alone are worth the $10, I'd say.

reviewText: BlazBlue: CT is a good fighting game that could have been a great if Arc System Works had only pushed the envelope a little more in terms of creativity. The visuals are nice, the controls are intuitive, and the extensive story mode makes for some entertaining reading. All of the fundamentals are in place. Nonetheless, Arcsys pushed this game out during a time when they legally couldn't make Guilty Gear games, and as a result, everything about this game smacks of a poor man's Guilty Gear. Anyone saying it isn't fair to compare the two series is delusional. Both games are the exact same flavor of fighter, but BlazBlue performs just a step below its sibling series in most regards. Every character on the roster is some transparent Bizarro World counterpart of someone from Guilty Gear. The music is the same metal style, but the melodies aren't as catchy aside from tunes that too closely resemble Guilty Gear pieces. The story is entertaining, but not as interesting. And the lack of online multiplayer in a PC port is a fault too glaring to omit. The overall gameplay, however, does manage to be on par with Arcsys's flagship fighter. Don't confuse my intentions; BlazBlue: CT is a good game in its own right. This brings me to my point: The developers didn't need to borrow so much from Guilty Gear. If you like the developer's other fighting offerings, you'll like this one, because it's almost the exact same thing. Arcsys would have done better to capitalize on the opportunity to create a more unique series, but instead, they came out with BlazBlue: Totally Not Guilty Gear, Sega.

reviewText:
People told me not to buy it, because it seemed horrible because of its 2D sprites and practically no one I know has heard of it. Didn't care, and I bought it.

Money was worth it.

Interface/Menu: 5/5 - The menu was original and was layed out very well. There's not much more than I can say about it, because the menu is pretty self explanatory, you've got your training button, arcade, story, exit button, score attack, and gallery. The music is very well made, thanks to Daisuke Ishiwatari. The circle layout in the select character screen fits the way the game works. I like the part where the random select is in the middle, which wasn't that self explanatory, I had to figure that out.

Gameplay: 4/5 - The gameplay is fluid and pretty simple, yet hard in some ways. You've got your weak, medium, hard, and drive attacks (A,B,C, and D), just like Injustice. Combo stringing is very open, as practically anything goes (An A,B,C will work for most characters). The mechanics are kind of hard to learn, such as the air recovery, ground recovery, barrier break, throw escapes, negative warning, and the barrier bar underneath each character's health. However, every character, except for Tager, has a double jump and air dash. This is one major part in the game, just like ground hits. There's also distortion drives and astral heats or finishes. These are moves that take 50%-100% of your heat bar. They perform stronger attacks, and your astral heat, always taking 100, will do a finisher, which is a nice touch to the game, adding some variety to the characters. For instance, with one character, you slice them with a scythe and then stab them with a sword, or on another character, you put them in an ice cage. Some characters have special distortion drives, like pushing you and your opponent, or even causing firey attacks, allowing you to go into a more powerful mode.

Story: 5/5 - The story is solid. However, in some cases, it doesn't all make sense. The stories intertwine with each others quite nicely, and even I haven't finished all of it. The cutscenes are nice, however not very fulfilling. The dialogue is very funny. Also allowing customization for the textbox is really neat.

Soundtrack/Music: 5/5 - The music is amazing, and gives BlazBlue the feeling that it needs. It's also included in the BlazBlue folder, allowing me to listen to it in the best quality.

Sprites/Animation: 3/5 - The sprites are good, and every detail is included into them, however the animation isn't all that fluid. However, it's probably the best you can get from a 2D game. However, some animations are fluid, like Rachel ducking and sitting on her cat. Don't complain people, it's the way it works.

reviewText:
Instantly rushed to buy this when I heard it got to Steam!!!

It feels like the developers were very inspired and a fan of their own creation. These are the people who made Guilty Gear, so yeah.

THE PROBLEM:
The big problem with this game is not with the game itself, it's with the port. What can be said for this port is it's terrible, it's really not good enough.
It's really disappointing and leaves the game vastly inferior to the console version.
The way they've set up the fighting for keyboard is ridiculous and I suggest you get a controller hooked up. Some menus you can't even go back from and you'll have to force the game to close, then relaunch it. There's no online versus mode in this port.
There are huge glaring problems with this port.
HOWEVER!
I'm willing to accept this. Later games in the franchise already improved on the game so Calamity Trigger is a little outdated in comparison. And here is why I think you should buy this.
For the sake of sequels. Show that there's an interest for this franchise to come to PC. This one doesn't cost much, and to me it shows this more of a product to test out the waters. If we show interest in this they'll probably invest more in a better team to port the sequels to PC (maybe fix this one) and just do this classic justice.
I can only speak well of BlazBlue and it frustrates me to see so many's first impression ruined by this port. Hate the port, don't hate the game and developers.

I've just come to love this game's style and its characters. In a way it's probably one of the most sophisticated and true fighting games in my opinion, all mechanically. The soundtrack is by the genius Daisuke Ishiwatari and it's amazing!
Very visually appealing and has some great voice acting for its kind, even in the English dub. It also scores some bonus points for sharing some voice actors with League of Legends. (fx. Noel - Riven, Hazama - Wukong, Tager - Garen)

It runs with sprite animations and it may not be what people are used to but it works just fine.
You don't really have to like anime to get into this I'd say, but if you're not into anime you may have to extend you tolerance quite a bit. It's story involves alot of space/time continuum and may be hard to follow but it's really good.
Maybe I'm wearing pink heart-shaped glasses here... I just really love this game's style.

Damn, I hope they release the rest on Steam. Let's keep a lookout for Continuum Shift and Chrono Phantasma!

reviewText:
As a person who grew up with playing Neo Geo's King of Fighter I can say that I did enjoy playing this game. Something that BlazBlue lacks is a large selection of characters (there are 12 in total). Though, because of that, every single character has their own unique fighting style and personality. The pace of this game is just right and the characters are somewhat balanced once you get a grip of their combos/attacks. BlazBlue's soundtracks are also great, more than that; they're included when you buy this game!

This game features a story mode which requires you to play through all character's story to unlock more content. It's basically a visual novel. With that said, there are different paths you can take which leads to different endings.
Surprisingly the story of this game was quite deep (complex?) and far more what I've expected. It was quite entertaining and it did add a lot more value to the game. The voice acting for some characters however (like Ragna) was terrible, while others (Rachel) was really good.

reviewText:
Step one...
If you're looking for a story mode review... scroll past, I haven't even touched it. Not at all.


To be fair, Balzblue gets a thumbs up because it works well for one, and looks great and runs smooth. It is a good fighting game that is complete and it adds elements that will probably get better over time.

However, for me, that's where it ends. For me, it feels like I'm playing soul calibur in 2d. Where certain characters can pretty much tap their way through all of your moves, or defeat you by actively countering all of your efforts and then relentlessly comboing you to death or near death and following up with the most bland way of killing you. And while it is obvious it needs to be a win or lose type of game, It does the game elements no justice at all to have regular ai in a game that could easily play insanely vibrantly like marvel vs capcom 3 or more accurately matrimelee.

Once you start playing or in my opinion, mashing, you'll notice Blazblue has tried their best to make every element count and have proper drawbacks, however, some more direct characters can actively push through the game with little to no technique, only to be floored by an ai that is akin to mugen making you suffer through some of the more tasteless but possible combos of the game. Things like rapid cancelling and air combos seem to have no proper airtime in the game although they could really REALLY show their stripes anywhere.

I don't know if they have stressed those mechanics in later games, And I do wish that the pc release has saw some sort of upgrade. However, as far as new fighting game IPs go, the later versions are usually large improvements over the last game, Though, when people boldly say Blazblue is the best 2d fighter made, I really want to ask them to name 5 fighting games and will flat out call them liars if they name any 2d fighting game with an intact air combo system. I hope they at least try to bring the latest release to steam and see what people do with it as a community, then actively fill in the gap of missing titles in the series... Because I am sure that this game is no longer an accurate summary of where the game has actually headed. And nobody is ever going to take the pc genre of the series seriously if most of the heavy hitters are just cash cows left to make devs direct income... showing from ill optimized titles like kof13 which pretty much runs like dry snot unless you can run games which actually need the power and skull girls which actually made a great anti piracy joke.

All in all, it is a fun game, however, there just doesn't feel like there's enough to leave this as a game in itself rather than another beat the ai title. Characters who are normally only for slapping around players who think you're going to do the obvious move or slash you into the cracks of the road are met with ai that is ready to grab your ankles to interrupt you and shoot a projectile while you're getting up to kill you off just as easy as they're willing to ground slash you as much as possible until you figure out it's basically soul calibur and unless you learn how to string together the foolproof-only-way-out-is-perfect-guard-combo, you'll be eating the equivalent down the line.

And before you swear it off for that, It's not too bad, but it does randomly turn into a cheese fest instead of just beat you. And you may find yourself using the simplest of moves and sticking to solid motions and attacks rather than what looks good when they do that, and it is sort of a shame that the battles do not really last long enough to literally combo foes upstage, or that you will waste so much energy trying to experience those elements when you can use the small array of specials they have properly and do exponentially more damage.

From my opinion, Tough sell at full price, yet good to have, but sour to know the genre is missing on pc. Lastly, It feels almost like a requirement to try to complete everything when the roster is this small, While in other games you have quite a bit before you've actually fought EVERYONE and feel like you need to pick up someone else rather than master or use only one person. And the fact they have unlockable super moves... Sigh... If you're even remotely a completionist you will have to do this. Anyway, nice game, far from the best fighter, great fighter on steam, Bring more love to steam.

The game also have some issues. They are not severe ones, but still some that showcase this version was not fully polished. But they do not break the game experience.

reviewText:
I've had this particular franchise for quite sometime on the console(s) and have bought almost every piece of content for it with the next step being to sell my body to Arksys.

For those who do not know, Blazblue Calamity Trigger is the first game in the fighting franchise, with Blazblue Continuum Shift being a sequel that has been released since 2009-2010, so seeing Calamity Trigger on the PC is quite a treat. The base game, as it should be, is the same as its console version, so if you require a review about it in general, there's quite a ton around.

Let's focus on the PC version.

Pros: - The controls are as fine as they ever were with gamepad support.

Cons: - No online multiplayer unlike its console version. (As stated on the store page)
- Limited graphical options. Anti-aliasing, some bloom effects, and resolutions being the only modifiable sets. Its            understandable considering the game's age as well as intended platform, but still disappointing nonetheless.
- In window mode, the max resolution is 1600 x 960.
- No mouse support. Although this is more of an optional piece rather than something that would've counted against the game, it would've been better with having the bare option.
- A character sprite GLITCH. When playing on full screen and in the middle of combat, if the game was alt-tabbed and reopened, both character sprites on screen will be invisible, leaving only their shadows to guide you.

All in all, as much as I am a fan of the franchise, I cannot recommend the game as is (the date of this review.) I thank H2 Interactive Co. for allowing this port to come to PC, but there are a few things that could've been better done. The lack of online mutliplayer restricts it to being a couch-local player game; granted there have been half-baked online multiplayer with terrible infrastructure. Blazblue on the PC is not at all a terrible port, but it doesn't live up to standard it had set on consoles.

reviewText:
Trying Too Hard

As a big fan of the Guilty Gear franchise, and Persona 4: Arena, I had...somewhat high hopes for this game. I'd heard what I'd heard, and little of it good, but still...a 7.5 wasn't too much to ask, was it?

This game is, in a nutshell, Guilty Gear if it was trying too hard. For someone who has played this, GG and P4A, it's so easy to see this as the middle child, with neither the love and care of the former, nor the time-tested wisdom of the latter.

The character designs in this game are atrocious. Each character has been over-designed to the point of becoming completely generic and uninteresting, a feat which I'd've thought impossible. Ragna the Bloodedge, a main character with a name somehow stupider than Sol Badguy, looks like an anime character merged with a matryoshka doll. You could shuck ten layers off this character and still not get to the actual man beneath. Every anime trope is piled on these characters in order to make them memorable, and a similar concept has been followed with the game's combat.

The Drive button is an interesting idea. I can see how it evolved into the P4A persona attacks. But here, it creates a combat system that is equal parts chaotic and clunky. I fully admit to scrub status; I am not particularly GOOD at Blazblue. But that is irrelevant here; I'm terrible at 3rd Strike, I'm terrible at P4A, I'm terrible at friggin Skullgirls; but it doesn't impact my enjoyment of the game.

With only local co-op available, the AI's gotta stand up. And it just doesn't. Set it to highest difficulty, pick Officer Moe, and spam Down+D. Oh, look what happened. PERFECT.

Is it? Is it really?

Main takeaway? People like to play fighting games for a lot of reasons, and the big two for me are the feel of the combat, and the design of the characters. And in both cases, Arcsys seems to have taken the approach of throw stuff at a wall and see what sticks."

What they didn't realize is that the wall was sticky. Very sticky.

For reasons.

Lookin' at you

reviewText:
Not for the feint of heart, BlazBlue is truly a 2D fighter of its own kind. The game is a fantastic exclamation point, and one that pushes the boundaries of 2D fighting games. It's a hardcore game that also can be fun to the amateurs of this genre, but make no mistake; the challenge is here if you want it. Overall, this is a wonderful addition to the genre and it exemplifies why 2D fighters are still alive and kicking.

At first glance the game is a beautiful masterpiece. All character models are drawn in high-res sprites. Backgrounds are done in 3D, and the blend of both equate to a wonderful convergence of visuals. The game is pretty to say the least. Each character also has a fun and quirky style reminiscent of Guilty Gear's lineage of outlandish character stock. We have cat girls, huge breasted beauties, mechanical marionettes, and countless odd yet cool fighters. If you can find your own quirk, there is bound to be a respectable character to scratch that itch within the game's 12 playable fighters.

Sound, too, boasts a caliber of oomph, which is usually accompanied by a mash-up of heavy metal riffs and classical music. While to some this might be an irritating soundtrack, I didn't find it to be annoying and it blended quite well with the high-intensity fights on screen. The one thing that can detract from the experience is the constant yelling and yelping that accompanies each move characters make. Some are more irritating than others (Tao for example comes to mind--meow, meow, meow...) but overall, the battle cries aren't excruciating, and after a few moments you drown it out into the background.

Gameplay itself is where the meat is, and with that players divulge into two camps; the ones that button mash, and those that take the time to master the mechanics. It's totally up to you how you approach the game, but to the dedicated they will find a rich experience to sink their teeth into. There are four attack buttons: weak, medium, strong, and Drive. The first three are self explanatory, the fourth, Drive, is a special attack that utilizes a characters special ability. While this array of button layout may seem tame compared to other fighters, in combination with quarter-circles, half-circles and the like, the game opens up considerably and the emphasis of quick dash and strike attacks takes over.

This is where the depth of the game shines. Knowing what moves and attacks do what kind of damage and how it affects the opponent is the key to opening up an opportunity to create a combo string. There are also two gauges, one controlling your guard and the other your super. Combine these with cancels, grabs and others, and you have quite and arsenal to kick some...well you know.

Once you think yourself decent, take the game to its various modes. You have your mandatory training, arcade and versus mode. These are self explanatory, but there are others. Story is an interesting change to the formula for this genre, as there is an actual story to follow. Granted the story here isn't amazing, but it is entertaining and the way the game forces you to choose different paths to unveil the whole story is interesting and a welcomed change to the usual we've seen before in this genre.

Along with story mode you have Score Attack (a variation of survivor mode) and Network, its online component. Online is pretty basic with player and ranked matches and you can watch a match along with four other people. The online mode is regular 1v1, but be forewarned, there are some top notch caliber people out there right now so you might be outgunned. If you have friends who have the game you can always set up a private match for a more balanced game. As of now, the online portion is very solid without any lag and most people whom I've come across have been cordial and stayed through the whole game. Obviously this can be different in your location but I live in Scotland and I've had zero lag issues online--two thumbs up to Arc Systems.

Overall, the game is a true keeper. If you are tired and feel Street Fighter and others alike have become stale, give this a definite buy.

BlazBlue is a MUST BUY.

BlazBlue: Calamity Trigger was ported over to the PC might be due to that the Games For Window Live version might be shutting down soon. But this was also done to see that if Arc System Works could port future titles to the PC. I'll cut to the chase right now. If you never played BlazBlue and you have a hunch for 2D Fighting games like Street Fighter then I highly reccomend BlazBlue: Calamity Trigger. Though if you already played this game before then there is no reason to go back into this port. But for Newcomers Calamity Trigger is Highly reccomened.

Developed by the people who made the wonderful Guilty Gear titles BlazBlue was basically the first real HD title to be devolped by Arcs. The game features 12 Characters all hand drawn and they look amazing. The fighting system uses four buttons and it easy to do stuff like quarter circle moves here and there. But if you really want to get most out of the game then practice you're combos well. Also I highly reccomened starting off with the beginner friendly characters like Ragna, Jin and Noel. Once you master thoes characters you can always move on to the other characters. As there is a steeper learning curve for the rest of cast like V-13, Haku-Men, Iron Tager, Litchi, Rachel and a few more. Also just about all of the characters play different from eachother as nobody has the same fighting style. Plus BlazBlue comes with a Super Deep storyline for a fighting game. It will keep you busy for quite sometime and the branching paths make everything awesome. The presentation is all anime style and if you're a fan of that you'll love the art. Music is also incredible with a Heavy Metal style soundtrack. The soundtrack for me is the biggest highlight of the game.

Also if there is one major nitpick with the PC version is that there is no online. Which is quite dissapointing for some of us to thoes who want to test there skills across the world. Hopefully a patch will come soon for an online. Overall BlazBlue: Calamity Trigger is a great fighting to really get into. Though if you already played this game before on consoles like Xbox 360 or Playstation 3 and the Windows version there isn't anything to make you head back to it. Plus the lack of online may turn some people off. But overall this a high quality fighting game that can sit and join the ranks on titles like Super Street Fighter IV: Arcade Edition and Mortal Kombat. reviewText:
Here it begins.

This is one of the (fully voiced) visual novel mashup games that alongside the Persona series forms the foundation for how I measure such things. It's also the first fighter of its format that I got any good at. The story is a gorgeous incompressible fractal, the character design is full of strong aesthetic persona that pushes all my buttons, and the mechanics are so good that lesser games such as the Street Fighter series are now unplayable to me.

The way the input buffer is built allows you to jam on a button and then overwrite the input if you change your mind before the attack actually launches, provided you're fast enough. In that way it plays more like Soul Calibur and less like Mortal Kombat. That input buffer is the biggest deciding factor in whether I buy a fighting game now. The quick-sticking system is also a godsend to new players: push the analog stick in one of the up or right to do a character-specific special move, left to do a super move, and down to do a finisher after you unlock them. This is a system that should be in all fighting games.

Also a part of the Brawl Minus school of gameplay balance: when every character is OP, no one is. Each character breaks the rules of the game in their own unique way from Tao's directional air dashes to Hakumen's counter button and autocharging specials to Nu 13's intangible-dash cancels and ability to attack anywhere on the screen if you're precise enough.

Pro tip tho: don't rely on integrated graphics to play it. My laptop chugs a bit, and as a very technical player this can throw me off considerably in more intense matches. That or I've gotten so fast that I need a new controller, because I'm inputting moves faster than the analog stick's sample rate.

The franchise is part of my Platinum Collection. On PS3/360 I've put over 2k hours combined into this series, and now I get to buy them all over again on Steam.

Hurry up and release Chrono Phantasma: Extend on Steam so I can buy that too.

reviewText:
Not for the feint of heart, BlazBlue is truly a 2D fighter of its own kind. The game is a fantastic exclamation point, and one that pushes the boundaries of 2D fighting games. It's a hardcore game that also can be fun to the amateurs of this genre, but make no mistake; the challenge is here if you want it. Overall, this is a wonderful addition to the genre and it exemplifies why 2D fighters are still alive and kicking.

At first glance the game is a beautiful masterpiece. All character models are drawn in high-res sprites. Backgrounds are done in 3D, and the blend of both equate to a wonderful convergence of visuals. The game is pretty to say the least. Each character also has a fun and quirky style reminiscent of Guilty Gear's lineage of outlandish character stock. We have cat girls, huge breasted beauties, mechanical marionettes, and countless odd yet cool fighters. If you can find your own quirk, there is bound to be a respectable character to scratch that itch within the game's 12 playable fighters.

Sound, too, boasts a caliber of oomph, which is usually accompanied by a mash-up of heavy metal riffs and classical music. While to some this might be an irritating soundtrack, I didn't find it to be annoying and it blended quite well with the high-intensity fights on screen. The one thing that can detract from the experience is the constant yelling and yelping that accompanies each move characters make. Some are more irritating than others (Tao for example comes to mind--meow, meow, meow...) but overall, the battle cries aren't excruciating, and after a few moments you drown it out into the background.

Gameplay itself is where the meat is, and with that players divulge into two camps; the ones that button mash, and those that take the time to master the mechanics. It's totally up to you how you approach the game, but to the dedicated they will find a rich experience to sink their teeth into. There are four attack buttons: weak, medium, strong, and Drive. The first three are self explanatory, the fourth, Drive, is a special attack that utilizes a characters special ability. While this array of button layout may seem tame compared to other fighters, in combination with quarter-circles, half-circles and the like, the game opens up considerably and the emphasis of quick dash and strike attacks takes over.

This is where the depth of the game shines. Knowing what moves and attacks do what kind of damage and how it affects the opponent is the key to opening up an opportunity to create a combo string. There are also two gauges, one controlling your guard and the other your super. Combine these with cancels, grabs and others, and you have quite and arsenal to kick some...well you know.

Once you think yourself decent, take the game to its various modes. You have your mandatory training, arcade and versus mode. These are self explanatory, but there are others. Story is an interesting change to the formula for this genre, as there is an actual story to follow. Granted the story here isn't amazing, but it is entertaining and the way the game forces you to choose different paths to unveil the whole story is interesting and a welcomed change to the usual we've seen before in this genre.

Along with story mode you have Score Attack (a variation of survivor mode) and Network, its online component. Online is pretty basic with player and ranked matches and you can watch a match along with four other people. The online mode is regular 1v1, but be forewarned, there are some top notch caliber people out there right now so you might be outgunned. If you have friends who have the game you can always set up a private match for a more balanced game. As of now, the online portion is very solid without any lag and most people whom I've come across have been cordial and stayed through the whole game. Obviously this can be different in your location but I live in Scotland and I've had zero lag issues online--two thumbs up to Arc Systems.

Overall, the game is a true keeper. If you are tired and feel Street Fighter and others alike have become stale, give this a definite buy.

BlazBlue is a MUST BUY.

reviewText:
Here it begins.

This is one of the (fully voiced) visual novel mashup games that alongside the Persona series forms the foundation for how I measure such things. It's also the first fighter of its format that I got any good at. The story is a gorgeous incompressible fractal, the character design is full of strong aesthetic persona that pushes all my buttons, and the mechanics are so good that lesser games such as the Street Fighter series are now unplayable to me.

The way the input buffer is built allows you to jam on a button and then overwrite the input if you change your mind before the attack actually launches, provided you're fast enough. In that way it plays more like Soul Calibur and less like Mortal Kombat. That input buffer is the biggest deciding factor in whether I buy a fighting game now. The quick-sticking system is also a godsend to new players: push the analog stick in one of the up or right to do a character-specific special move, left to do a super move, and down to do a finisher after you unlock them. This is a system that should be in all fighting games.

Also a part of the Brawl Minus school of gameplay balance: when every character is OP, no one is. Each character breaks the rules of the game in their own unique way from Tao's directional air dashes to Hakumen's counter button and autocharging specials to Nu 13's intangible-dash cancels and ability to attack anywhere on the screen if you're precise enough.

Pro tip tho: don't rely on integrated graphics to play it. My laptop chugs a bit, and as a very technical player this can throw me off considerably in more intense matches. That or I've gotten so fast that I need a new controller, because I'm inputting moves faster than the analog stick's sample rate.

The franchise is part of my Platinum Collection. On PS3/360 I've put over 2k hours combined into this series, and now I get to buy them all over again on Steam.

Hurry up and release Chrono Phantasma: Extend on Steam so I can buy that too.
